  16. (* Entry points in the parser *)

  18. (* Skip tokens to the end of the phrase *)

  20. ‌let last_token = ref Parser.EOF

  22. ‌let token lexbuf =
  23.   let token = Lexer.token lexbuf in
  24.   last_token := token;
  25.   token

  27. ‌let rec skip_phrase lexbuf =
  28.   match token lexbuf with
  29.   | Parser.SEMISEMI | Parser.EOF -> ()
  30.   | _ -> skip_phrase lexbuf
  31.   | exception (Lexer.Error (Lexer.Unterminated_comment _, _)
  32.               | Lexer.Error (Lexer.Unterminated_string, _)
  33.               | Lexer.Error (Lexer.Reserved_sequence _, _)
  34.               | Lexer.Error (Lexer.Unterminated_string_in_comment _, _)
  35.               | Lexer.Error (Lexer.Illegal_character _, _)) ->
  36.       skip_phrase lexbuf

  38. ‌let maybe_skip_phrase lexbuf =
  39.   match !last_token with
  40.   | Parser.SEMISEMI | Parser.EOF -> ()
  41.   | _ -> skip_phrase lexbuf

  43. ‌type 'a parser =
  44.   (Lexing.lexbuf -> Parser.token) -> Lexing.lexbuf -> 'a

  46. ‌let wrap (parser : 'a parser) lexbuf : 'a =
  47.   try
  48.     Docstrings.init ();
  49.     Lexer.init ();
  50.     let ast = parser token lexbuf in
  51.     Parsing.clear_parser();
  52.     Docstrings.warn_bad_docstrings ();
  53.     last_token := Parser.EOF;
  54.     ast
  55.   with
  56.   | Lexer.Error(Lexer.Illegal_character _, _) as err
  57.     when !Location.input_name = "//toplevel//"->
  58.       skip_phrase lexbuf;
  59.       raise err
  60.   | Syntaxerr.Error _ as err
  61.     when !Location.input_name = "//toplevel//" ->
  62.       maybe_skip_phrase lexbuf;
  63.       raise err
  64.   | Parsing.Parse_error | Syntaxerr.Escape_error ->
  65.       let loc = Location.curr lexbuf in
  66.       if !Location.input_name = "//toplevel//"
  67.       then maybe_skip_phrase lexbuf;
  68.       raise(Syntaxerr.Error(Syntaxerr.Other loc))

  70. (* We pass [--strategy simplified] to Menhir, which means that we wish to use
  71.    its "simplified" strategy for handling errors. When a syntax error occurs,
  72.    the current token is replaced with an [error] token. The parser then
  73.    continues shifting and reducing, as far as possible. After (possibly)
  74.    shifting the [error] token, though, the parser remains in error-handling
  75.    mode, and does not request the next token, so the current token remains
  76.    [error].

  78.    In OCaml's grammar, the [error] token always appears at the end of a
  79.    production, and this production always raises an exception. In such
  80.    a situation, the strategy described above means that:

  82.    - either the parser will not be able to shift [error],
  83.      and will raise [Parser.Error];

  85.    - or it will be able to shift [error] and will then reduce
  86.      a production whose semantic action raises an exception.

  88.    In either case, the parser will not attempt to read one token past
  89.    the syntax error. *)

  91. ‌let implementation = wrap Parser.implementation
  92. and interface = wrap Parser.interface
  93. and toplevel_phrase = wrap Parser.toplevel_phrase
  94. and use_file = wrap Parser.use_file
  95. and core_type = wrap Parser.parse_core_type
  96. and expression = wrap Parser.parse_expression
  97. and pattern = wrap Parser.parse_pattern
  98. ‌let module_type = wrap Parser.parse_module_type
  99. ‌let module_expr = wrap Parser.parse_module_expr

  101. ‌let longident = wrap Parser.parse_any_longident
  102. ‌let val_ident = wrap Parser.parse_val_longident
  103. ‌let constr_ident= wrap Parser.parse_constr_longident
  104. ‌let extended_module_path = wrap Parser.parse_mod_ext_longident
  105. ‌let simple_module_path = wrap Parser.parse_mod_longident
  106. ‌let type_ident = wrap Parser.parse_mty_longident

  108. (* Error reporting for Syntaxerr *)
  109. (* The code has been moved here so that one can reuse Pprintast.tyvar *)

  111. ‌let prepare_error err =
  112.   let open Syntaxerr in
  113.   match err with
  114.   | Unclosed(opening_loc, opening, closing_loc, closing) ->
  115.       Location.errorf
  116.         ~loc:closing_loc
  117.         ~sub:[
  118.           Location.msg ~loc:opening_loc
  119.             "This '%s' might be unmatched" opening
  120.         ]
  121.         "Syntax error: '%s' expected" closing

  123.   | Expecting (loc, nonterm) ->
  124.       Location.errorf ~loc "Syntax error: %s expected." nonterm
  125.   | Not_expecting (loc, nonterm) ->
  126.       Location.errorf ~loc "Syntax error: %s not expected." nonterm
  127.   | Applicative_path loc ->
  128.       Location.errorf ~loc
  129.         "Syntax error: applicative paths of the form F(X).t \
  130.          are not supported when the option -no-app-func is set."
  131.   | Variable_in_scope (loc, var) ->
  132.       Location.errorf ~loc
  133.         "In this scoped type, variable %a \
  134.          is reserved for the local type %s."
  135.         Pprintast.tyvar var var
  136.   | Other loc ->
  137.       Location.errorf ~loc "Syntax error"
  138.   | Ill_formed_ast (loc, s) ->
  139.       Location.errorf ~loc
  140.         "broken invariant in parsetree: %s" s
  141.   | Invalid_package_type (loc, s) ->
  142.       Location.errorf ~loc "invalid package type: %s" s
  143.   | Removed_string_set loc ->
  144.       Location.errorf ~loc
  145.         "Syntax error: strings are immutable, there is no assignment \
  146.          syntax for them.\n\
  147.          @{<hint>Hint@}: Mutable sequences of bytes are available in \
  148.          the Bytes module.\n\
  149.          @{<hint>Hint@}: Did you mean to use 'Bytes.set'?"
  150. let () =
  151.   Location.register_error_of_exn
  152.     (function
  153.       | Syntaxerr.Error err -> Some (prepare_error err)
  154.       | _ -> None
  155.     )
